art.capt: cotton: 1 flowering branch; 2 fruit, unopened; 3 fruit, partly opened

entry.et: Middle English coton, from Anglo-French cotun, from Old Italian cotone, from Arabic quṭun, quṭn

def.dt: :a soft usually white fibrous substance composed of the hairs surrounding the seeds of various erect freely branching tropical plants (genus Gossypium) of the mallow family
:a plant producing cotton
:one grown for its cotton
:a crop of cotton
:fabric made of cotton
:yarn spun from cotton
:a downy cottony substance produced by various plants (as the cottonwood)

art.cap: cotton: 1 flowering branch; 2 fruit, unopened; 3 fruit, partly opened

def.dt: :to take a liking used with to cottons to people easily
:to come to understand used with to or on to cottoned on to the fact that our children work furiously H. M. McLuhan
Charles 1630–1687 Eng. author & translator
John 1585–1652 Am. (Eng.-born) Puritan clergyman
:corn earworm
:a candy made of spun sugar
:something attractive but insubstantial
:a machine that separates the seeds, hulls, and foreign material from cotton
:any of a genus (Eriophorum) of sedges with tufted spikes
:damned used as a generalized expression of disapproval a cotton–picking hypocrite
:damned used as an intensive out of his cotton–picking mind Irving Kristol
:any of several bugs (genus Dysdercus) that damage and stain the lint of developing cotton
:a red and brown bug (D. suturellus) that attacks cotton in the southern United States
